nexttext:
where $A$ generates a strongly continuous semigroup $\{\Phi(t)\}_{t\geq 0}$ on the Hilbert
space $Z:=H^1(\Omega)$, $z\in L^2(0,b;Z)$  and the initial vector $z_0\in Z$. It is supposed
that  $B: \mathbf{R}^p\to Z$ is the control operator and $u\in L^2(0,b;\mathbf{R}^p)$ depends
on the number and structure of actuators.
Moreover, the
Riemann-Liouville fractional derivative $_0D_t^\alpha$ and the Riemann-Liouville fractional
integral $_0I^{\alpha}_t$  are, respectively, given by \cite{Podlubny},\cite{Kilbas}
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}{}_{0}D^{\alpha}_{t}z(t)=Az(t)+Bu(t),~{}~{}t\in[0,b],%
\\
\lim\limits_{t\to 0^{+}}{}_{0}I^{1-\alpha}_{t}z(t)=z_{0},\end{array}\right." display="block"><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mmultiscripts><mi>D</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>α</mi><mprescripts/><mn>0</mn><none/></mmultiscripts><mo>⁢</mo><mi>z</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>z</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>u</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="9.1pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>b</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><munder><mo movablelimits="false">lim</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mn>0</mn><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow></munder><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mmultiscripts><mi>I</mi><mi>t</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow><mprescripts/><mn>0</mn><none/></mmultiscripts><mo>⁢</mo><mi>z</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>z</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable><mi/></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\begin{definition} \cite{GeFDTA-rc}\label{lemma2.1} For any given $f\in  L^2\left(0,b; Z\right),$ $\alpha\in (0,1],$
a function $v\in L^2\left(0,b; Z\right)$  is said to be a mild solution of the following system
prevtext:
where $A$ generates a strongly continuous semigroup $\{\Phi(t)\}_{t\geq 0}$ on the Hilbert
space $Z:=H^1(\Omega)$, $z\in L^2(0,b;Z)$  and the initial vector $z_0\in Z$. It is supposed
that  $B: \mathbf{R}^p\to Z$ is the control operator and $u\in L^2(0,b;\mathbf{R}^p)$ depends
on the number and structure of actuators.
Moreover, the
Riemann-Liouville fractional derivative $_0D_t^\alpha$ and the Riemann-Liouville fractional
integral $_0I^{\alpha}_t$  are, respectively, given by \cite{Podlubny},\cite{Kilbas}
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="_{0}D_{t}^{\alpha}z(t)=\frac{d}{dt}{}_{0}I_{t}^{1-\alpha}z(t),~{}~{}\alpha\in(%
0,1]~{}\mbox{ and }~{}{}_{0}I^{\alpha}_{t}z(t)=\frac{1}{\Gamma(\alpha)}\int^{t%
}_{0}{(t-s)^{\alpha-1}z(s)ds},~{}~{}\alpha>0." display="block"><mrow><msub><mi/><mn>0</mn></msub><msubsup><mi>D</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>α</mi></msubsup><mi>z</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>d</mi><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mmultiscripts><mi>I</mi><mi>t</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow><mprescripts/><mn>0</mn><none/></mmultiscripts><mi>z</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo rspace="9.1pt">,</mo><mi>α</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo rspace="5.8pt" stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mtext> and </mtext></mpadded><mmultiscripts><mi>I</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>α</mi><mprescripts/><mn>0</mn><none/></mmultiscripts><mi>z</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>α</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mi>t</mi></msubsup><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mi>z</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>s</mi><mo rspace="9.1pt">,</mo><mi>α</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
\begin{definition} \cite{GeFDTA-rc}\label{lemma2.1} For any given $f\in  L^2\left(0,b; Z\right),$ $\alpha\in (0,1],$
a function $v\in L^2\left(0,b; Z\right)$  is said to be a mild solution of the following system
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}{}_{0}D^{\alpha}_{t}v(t)=Av(t)+f(t),~{}t\in[0,b],\\
\lim\limits_{t\to 0^{+}}{}_{0}I_{t}^{1-\alpha}v(t)=v_{0}\in Z,\end{array}\right." display="block"><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mmultiscripts><mi>D</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>α</mi><mprescripts/><mn>0</mn><none/></mmultiscripts><mo>⁢</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>b</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><munder><mo movablelimits="false">lim</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mn>0</mn><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow></munder><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mmultiscripts><mi>I</mi><mi>t</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow><mprescripts/><mn>0</mn><none/></mmultiscripts><mo>⁢</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>∈</mo><mi>Z</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable><mi/></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="K^{*}_{\alpha}(t)=\alpha\int_{0}^{\infty}{\theta\phi_{\alpha}(\theta)\Phi^{*}(%
t^{\alpha}\theta)}d\theta." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>K</mi><mi>α</mi><mo>*</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup><mrow><mi>θ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ϕ</mi><mi>α</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mo>*</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>t</mi><mi>α</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="E_{\alpha,\alpha}(t)>0~{}(t\geq 0)\mbox{ and }(p_{D},\xi_{ij})_{Z}=\frac{2a_{%
ij}}{j\pi}\left[\sin(j\pi/2)+j\pi(\cos(j\pi/2)-1)\right],~{}j=1,2,\cdots," display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>></mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mn>0</mn></mpadded><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mtext> and </mtext><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>p</mi><mi>D</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>ξ</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>Z</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mfrac><mrow><mo>[</mo><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>j</mi><mi>π</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>j</mi><mi>π</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>cos</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>j</mi><mi>π</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">,</mo><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Moreover, we suppose that $-A$ is a self-adjoint uniformly elliptic operator,
by \cite{Hilbert}, we get that
there exists a sequence $(\lambda_j,\xi_{jk}): k=1,2,\cdots,r_j$, $j=1,2,\cdots $
such that

$(1)$ For each $ j=1,2,\cdots$, $\lambda_j$ is the eigenvalue of operator $A$ with multiplicities $r_j$ and
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}{}_{0}D^{\alpha}_{t}z(t,x)=Az(t,x)+\sum\limits_{i=1}^%
{p}{p_{D_{i}}g_{i}(x)u_{i}(t)},~{}(t,x)\in[0,b]\times\Omega,\\
\lim\limits_{t\to 0^{+}}{}_{0}I^{1-\alpha}_{t}z(t,x)=z_{0}(x).\end{array}\right." display="block"><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mmultiscripts><mi>D</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>α</mi><mprescripts/><mn>0</mn><none/></mmultiscripts><mo>⁢</mo><mi>z</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>z</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>p</mi></munderover><mrow><msub><mi>p</mi><msub><mi>D</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>u</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>b</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><munder><mo movablelimits="false">lim</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mn>0</mn><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow></munder><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mmultiscripts><mi>I</mi><mi>t</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow><mprescripts/><mn>0</mn><none/></mmultiscripts><mo>⁢</mo><mi>z</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo nexttext: $(2)$ For each $ j=1,2,\cdots$,  $\xi_{jk}(k=1,2,\cdots,r_j)$ is the orthonormal eigenfunction corresponding to $\lambda_j$, i.e.,
prevtext:
Moreover, we suppose that $-A$ is a self-adjoint uniformly elliptic operator,
by \cite{Hilbert}, we get that
there exists a sequence $(\lambda_j,\xi_{jk}): k=1,2,\cdots,r_j$, $j=1,2,\cdots $
such that

$(1)$ For each $ j=1,2,\cdots$, $\lambda_j$ is the eigenvalue of operator $A$ with multiplicities $r_j$ and
$(2)$ For each $ j=1,2,\cdots$,  $\xi_{jk}(k=1,2,\cdots,r_j)$ is the orthonormal eigenfunction corresponding to $\lambda_j$, i.e.,
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="(\xi_{jk_{m}},\xi_{jk_{n}})=\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}1,~{}~{}k_{m}=k_{n},\\

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}Q{}_{t}D^{\alpha}_{b}\left[(b-t)^{1-\alpha}\varphi(x,%
t)\right]=A^{*}Q\left[(b-t)^{1-\alpha}\varphi(x,t)\right]~{}\mbox{ in }~{}%
\Omega\times[0,b],\\
\lim\limits_{t\to 0^{+}}Q{}_{t}I^{1-\alpha}_{b}\left[(b-t)^{1-\alpha}\varphi(x%
,t)\right]=p_{\omega_{r}}^{*}g(x)~{}\mbox{ in }~{}\Omega,\\
\varphi(x,t)=0~{}\mbox{ on }~{}\partial\Omega\times[0,b].\end{array}\right." display="block"><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mtext> in </mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><mo>×</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>b</mi><mo nexttext:
and its unique mild solution is
$\varphi(x,t)=(b-t)^{\alpha-1}K_\alpha^*(b-t)p_{\omega_r}^*g(x).$
Moreover, we define the semi-norm
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}{}_{0}D^{\alpha}_{t}Q\left[(b-t)^{1-\alpha}\varphi(x,%
t)\right]=A^{*}Q\left[(b-t)^{1-\alpha}\varphi(x,t)\right]~{}\mbox{ in }~{}%
\Omega\times[0,b],\\

,t)\right]=p_{\omega_{r}}^{*}g(x)~{}\mbox{ in }~{}\Omega,\\
\varphi(x,t)=0~{}\mbox{ on }~{}\partial\Omega\times[0,b]\end{array}\right." display="block"><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd Moreover, we define the semi-norm

mathml:

}f(x)\left(f,\varphi(\cdot,t)\right)_{L^{2}(D)}~{}\mbox{ in }~{}\Omega\times[0%
,b],\\
